26  Presently before the Court  is Defendant and Counterclaimant CoreCivic, Inc.โs 
27  (โDefendantโ) Motion to Stay (โMot.,โ ECF No. 285) and Memorandum of Points and 
28  Authorities  in  Support  Thereof  (โMem.,โ  ECF  No.  285-1).    Plaintiffs  and 
1 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9987     Page 2
of 11
 
1  Counterdefendants Sylvester Owino and Jonathan Gomez (collectively, โPlaintiffsโ) filed 
2  an Opposition to the Motion (โOppโn,โ ECF No. 286), and Defendant filed a Reply 
3  (โReply,โ ECF No. 288).  The Court vacated the hearing on Defendantโs Motion and took 
4  it under submission pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7.1(d)(1).  See ECF No. 287.  Having 
5  carefully considered the Partiesโ arguments, the evidence, and the law, the Court GRANTS 
6  IN PART AND DENIES IN PART Defendantโs Motion.   
7  BACKGROUND 
8    As the Parties are familiar with the facts, the Court incorporates by reference the 
9  factual and procedural background set forth in this Courtโs April 1, 2020 and November 2, 
10  2023 Orders, and states here only the background relevant to the present Motion.  
11    This case involves allegations that Defendantโa company that operates detention 
12  facilities for civil immigration detaineesโ(1) violated Californiaโs labor laws with respect 
13  to detaineesโ voluntary work and (2) coerced detainees to perform uncompensated work in 
14  violation of both California and federal law.  ECF No. 179 at 2โ3.  Among other causes of 
15  action, the operative First Amended Complaint (โFACโ) alleges violations of the federal 
16  Trafficking Victims Protection Act (โTVPAโ), 18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1581โ97.  ECF No. 67 at 
17  12โ15.  On April 1, 2020, the Court certified three classes, two of which involve only 
18  California-based detainees.  See ECF No. 179 at 12, 59.  The third class (the โNational 
19  Forced Labor Classโ) includes detainees at all of Defendantโs facilities.  Id.   
20    This case has been pending for almost seven years.  For much of that time, this case 
21  has been mired in time-consuming discovery.  See, e.g., ECF No. 224 at 7โ9 (describing 
22  Defendantโs estimates of the cost and time burdens associated with class discovery and 
23  noting  that  Defendant  had  โdelay[ed]  in  complying  with  its  discovery  obligationsโ).  
24  Moreover, this case was stayed in part for approximately two years pending the resolution 
25  of an interlocutory appeal.  ECF Nos. 224, 261.  
26  The  Parties  are  currently  engaged  in  discovery  relating  to  Defendantโs  non-
27  California  facilities  and  Plaintiffsโ  federal  TVPA  claim.    See  ECF  No.  284  at  2โ3.  
28  Defendant represents this discovery will take one year to complete.  Id.  Aside from the 
2 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9988     Page 3
of 11
 
1  one-year deadline imposed on this discovery, no scheduling order is currently in place.  See 
2  id. at 3 (requiring the parties to file a status report on February 27, 2025, that includes a 
3  proposed  scheduling  order);  ECF  No.  237  (vacating  pretrial  conference  and  related 
4  deadlines in light of appeal-related stay). 
5    Approximately  one  month  after  United  States  Magistrate  Judge  Steve  B.  Chu 
6  resolved the Partiesโ most recent discovery dispute, Defendant filed the instant Motion.  
7  Defendant seeks to stay this case in its entirety pending the Ninth Circuitโs rulings in 
8  Nwauzor v. GEO Group, Inc., No. 21-36024, and Washington v. GEO Group, Inc., No. 21-
9  36025 (collectively, โNwauzorโ).   
10  LEGAL STANDARD 
11  District courts have โbroad discretionโ to stay actions pending before them.  Clinton 
12  v. Jones, 520 U.S. 681, 706 (1997).  This discretion includes the power to stay an action 
13  pending resolution of independent proceedings if โit is efficient for [the courtโs] own 
14  docket and the fairest course for the parties.โ  Leyva v. Certified Grocers of Cal., 593 F.2d 
15  857, 863 (9th Cir. 1979).  When determining whether a stay is appropriate, courts must 
16  consider (1) โthe possible damage which may result from the granting of a stay,โ (2) โthe 
17  hardship or inequity which a party may suffer in being required to go forward,โ and (3) โthe 
18  simplifying or complicating of issues, proof, and questions of law which could be expected 
19  to result from a stay.โ  CMAX, Inc. v. Hall, 300 F.2d 265, 268 (9th Cir. 1962).  โ[I]f there 
20  is even a fair possibility that the stay for which [the moving party] prays will work damage 
21  to someone else,โ the moving party must โmake out a clear case of hardship or inequity in 
22  being required to go forward.โ  Landis v. N. Am. Co., 299 U.S. 248, 255 (1936).  Moreover, 
23  โ[a] stay should not be granted unless it appears likely the [independent] proceedings will 
24  be concluded within a reasonable time in relation to the urgency of the claims presented to 
25  the court.โ  Leyva, 593 F.2d at 864. 
26  DISCUSSION 
27    In Nwauzor, appellant GEO Group, Inc. (โGEOโ)โa private company operating 
28  detention facilities for civil immigration detaineesโargues that two federal district courts 
3 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9989     Page 4
of 11
 
1  erred in concluding that Washington minimum wage law applied to civil immigration 
2  detainees held pursuant to a contract between GEO and the federal government.  Opening 
3  Brief of Defendant-Appellant at 1โ3, Nwauzor v. GEO Grp., Inc., No. 21-36024 (9th Cir. 
4  Mar. 21, 2022), ECF No. 18.  After hearing oral argument, the Ninth Circuit certified 
5  questions of state law to the Washington Supreme Court, Nwauzor, 62 F.4th 509, 516โ17 
6  (9th Cir. 2023), which the Washington Supreme Court resolved in appelleesโ favor on 
7  January 11, 2023, Nwauzor v. GEO Grp., Inc., 540 P.3d 93, 96 (Wash. 2023).  The 
8  Nwauzor parties and the United States then engaged in supplemental briefing1 on the 
9  application of three constitutional defenses to the plaintiffsโ state law claims: preemption, 
10  intergovernmental immunity, and derivative sovereign immunity.  See Order, Nwauzor, 
11  No. 21-36024 (9th Cir. Mar. 7, 2023), ECF No. 95; Order, Nwauzor, No. 21-36024 (9th 
12  Cir. Feb. 23, 2024), ECF No. 116.  Those same defenses are at issue in this action.   
13    Per Defendant, considerations of judicial economy support staying this case in its 
14  entirety until the Ninth Circuit issues an opinion in Nwauzor.  Defendant argues that delay 
15  alone does not constitute prejudice to Plaintiffs, Mem. at 7; monetary damages incurred by 
16  class members during the stay are compensable at trial, id. at 8; continued litigation on 
17  state law claims that might be subject to the same defenses at issue in Nwauzor causes 
18  unnecessary hardship, id. at 9; and declining to proceed further at this time preserves 
19  judicial resources, id. at 10.  
20    Plaintiffs respond that regardless of the outcome in Nwauzor, their federal TVPA 
21  claims will survive.  Oppโn at 1.  Therefore, per Plaintiffs, โthere is no reason why the 
22  claims of the Forced Labor Classes should not proceed at this time.โ  Id. at 3.  They also 
23  contend that (1) they โreasonably expect that the Ninth Circuit will resolve [Nwauzor] 
24  before Plaintiffs can renew their [motion for partial summary judgment as to state law 
25  claims],โ id. at 4; (2) โthere are no pressing deadlines or exigencies in this action weighing 
26 
 
27 
1 As supplemental briefing in Nwauzor has only recently concluded, the Ninth Circuit has yet to indicate 
28 
whether it will order additional oral argument.   
4 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9990     Page 5
of 11
 
1  in favor of a stay,โ as โall the outstanding [electronically stored information (โESIโ)] 
2  CoreCivic will collect and produce over the next yearโ relates to Plaintiffsโ federal TVPA 
3  claims, id. at 5; and (3) the longer the case drags on, the harder it will be for Plaintiffs to 
4  find relevant information and contact putative class members, id. at 6.   
5    For the reasons that follow, the Court largely agrees with Plaintiffs.  The Court first 
6  addresses Defendantโs argument that this case should be stayed in its entirety.  The Court 
7  then proceeds Defendantโs alternative request that this action be stayed only as to Plaintiffsโ 
8  state law claims.   
9  I.  Case as a Whole 
10  A.  Possible Damage to Plaintiffs 
11    Defendant contends delay will not prejudice Plaintiffs because any continuing harm 
12  they face will be redressed by monetary damages.  Mem. at 7.  Not so.  As another court 
13  recognized in a similar case, forced labor causes harms that โare not solely financial.โ  
14  Novoa v. GEO Grp., Inc., No. EDCV172514JGBSHKX, 2022 WL 2189624, at *2 (C.D. 
15  Cal. Mar. 31, 2022).  And compensation for suffering does not erase suffering.  Regardless 
16  of  whether  class  members  will  receive  monetary  compensation  for  their  continued 
17  exposure to alleged forced labor, the harm associated with said exposure weighs against a 
18  stay.  See id. 
19    Second,  the  Court  is  concerned  regarding  the  impact  of  continued  delay  on 
20  โ[e]vidence,  witness  availability,  and  memory  concerning  the  pertinent  time  frame.โ  
21  Interwoven, Inc. v. Vertical Comput. Sys., Inc., No. C 10-04645 RS, 2012 WL 761692, at 
22  *3 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 8, 2012).  This case has been pending for seven years.  The longer it 
23  stretches on, the more likely it is that probative evidence will slip out of reach.  This 
24  potential prejudice similarly weighs against a stay.  See In re Morning Song Bird Food 
25  Litig., 320 F.R.D. 540, 543โ45 (S.D. Cal. 2017) (finding, in a case that had been pending 
26  for nearly five years, that continued stay-related delay โwould serve to prejudice Plaintiffโ).   
27  / / / 
28  / / / 
5 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9991     Page 6
of 11
 
1  B.  Hardship to Defendant 
2    Because the Court has found that a stay would wreak possible damage to Plaintiffs, 
3  Defendant must โmake out a clear case of hardship or inequity.โ  Landis, 299 U.S. at 255.  
4  Defendant has not done so here.  
5    As this litigation will likely continue in some fashion regardless of the outcome in 
6  Nwauzor, Defendantโs arguments regarding wasteful discovery are entitled to little weight.  
7  Defendant repeatedly asserts that โ[a]ny one of the constitutional defenses now before the 
8  Ninth Circuit could result in the dismissal of part or all of the claims in this case.โ  Mem. 
9  at 8 (emphasis added).  Yet Defendant fails to explain how the defenses relevant to the 
10  Nwauzor  plaintiffsโ  state  law  claims  would  impact  Plaintiffsโ  federal  TVPA  claim.  
11  Defendantโs silence in this regard is glaring given (1) its clear explanation of how Nwauzor 
12  would impact Plaintiffsโ state law claims, see Mem. at 9; and (2) Plaintiffsโ express 
13  contention that Nwauzor has โno arguable bearing on the Forced Labor Classes,โ Oppโn. 
14  at 3; see also Novoa, 2022 WL 2189624, at *3 (โ[A]s Plaintiffs note, GEOโs affirmative 
15  defenses  do  not  affect  Plaintiffsโ  federal  TVPA  claims.โ).    As  there  will  likely  โbe 
16  unresolved issues in need of discovery regardless of the outcome of [Nwauzor],โ Defendant 
17  cannot rely on the burden associated with discovery on said issues to justify a stay.  See 
18  Montegna  v.  Ocwen  Loan  Servicing,  LLC,  No.  17-CV-00939-AJB-BLM,  2017  WL 
19  4680168, at *4 (S.D. Cal. Oct. 18, 2017).  
20    This conclusion is reinforced by the status of discovery.  The only current discovery 
21  deadline in this case involves Defendantโs production of ESI from non-California facilities 
22  โin connection with the TVPA claim of the National Forced Labor Class.โ  Oppโn at 7.  
23  And Defendant represented that this discovery will take an entire year to complete.  See 
24  ECF No. 284 at 3 (granting Defendantโs request for one year to complete its TVPA-related 
25  discovery obligations).  Thus, until early 2025, Defendant will be engaged in discovery 
26  that Defendant does not dispute will be unaffected by Nwauzor.   
27  Consequently, Defendant has not shown sufficient hardship to justify a stay of this 
28  action in its entirety. See Montegna, 2017 WL 4680168, at *4 (โ[R]equiring both parties to 
6 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9992     Page 7
of 11
 
1  engage in conduct they would unavoidably have to in any event does not warrant an 
2  imposition of a delay that would cause a matter to come to a grinding halt.โ).   
3  C.  Simplifying and Complicating of Issues 
4    The Court agrees with Defendant thatโas Plaintiffs do not disputeโthe Ninth 
5  Circuitโs opinion in Nwauzor will likely simplify the issues before this court.  Depending 
6  on the outcome, Nwauzor may either demonstrate that Plaintiffsโ state law claims are 
7  barred by one of Defendantโs constitutional defenses or obviate the need for this Court to 
8  consider  Defendantโs  constitutional  defenses.    Based  on  the  current  posture  of  this 
9  litigation, however, it seems likely that the Court will benefit from Nwauzorโs guidance 
10  regardless of whether it stays this case in its entirety.   
11  A comparison with similar cases is instructive. In Gomez v. GEO Group, Inc., the 
12  court granted a stay where it was faced with a pending motion to dismiss, motion for partial 
13  class certification, and motion for summary judgment, all of which involved issues tied up 
14  in Nwauzor.  No. 122CV00868ADACDB, 2023 WL 4424586, at *1โ2 (E.D. Cal. July 10, 
15  2023).  Rather than spend judicial resources ruling on these pending motions, the Court 
16  stayed the case in its entirety.  Id. at *4.  In Novoa, by contrast, the case was in an advanced 
17  stageโthe court had already certified a class and ruled on cross-motions for summary 
18  judgment.  2022 WL 2189624, at *1.  As all that was left to do in Novoa was trial, judicial 
19  economy again counseled against engaging in lengthy and expensive proceedings that 
20  might give rise to inconsistent or unnecessary rulings.  Id. at *3.   
21    This case is at a different stage from Gomez and Novoa.  This Court has already 
22  resolved Defendantโs motion to dismiss and has certified multiple classes.  ECF Nos. 38, 
23  179.  And as the Parties are currently engaged in lengthy discovery, see ECF No. 284, there 
24  are  no  approaching dispositive-motion  or  trial deadlines that  threaten  to give  rise  to 
25  inconsistent or unnecessary rulings.  The current absence of such deadlines further weighs 
26  against a stay of this case.   
27    All three factors weigh against staying this action in its entirety.  The Court therefore 
28  DENIES Defendantโs request to the extent Defendant seeks such a stay. 
7 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9993     Page 8
of 11
 
1  II.  Stay as to State Law Claims Only 
2    Though Defendant in its Motion seeks only a stay of this action in its entirety, 
3  Defendant in its Reply asks the Court to โat a minimum . . . stay further proceedings 
4  pertaining to Plaintiffsโ state law claims.โ  Reply at 6โ7.  Defendant first argues that it 
5  would waste judicial resources to issue dispositive rulings on state law claims that might 
6  be mooted by Nwauzor.  Second, Defendant suggests it should not have to bear the expense 
7  of claim-specific discovery that might ultimately prove unnecessary.  Finally, Defendant 
8  contends notice should not be sent to class members whose claims may be dismissed. 
9    The Court will issue a limited stay as to dispositive motions regarding state law 
10  claims potentially subject to the constitutional defenses at issue in Nwauzor.  The Court 
11  agrees that โ[w]aiting for a decision to issue in [Nwauzor] will โavoid exhausting judicial 
12  resources  to  decide . . . summary  judgment  motions . . . which  may  prove  fruitless.โโ  
13  Gomez, 2023 WL 4424586, at *4.  Indeed, Plaintiffs do not contend that it makes sense for 
14  this Court to rule on state law claims that could well be barred if the Ninth Circuit rules in 
15  favor of GEO Group.  Instead, they argue only that the Ninth Circuit will likely issue its 
16  ruling in Nwauzor before Plaintiffs are able to file their  anticipated partial summary 
17  judgment motion.  Oppโn at 4.  As both Parties agree that the Ninth Circuitโs ruling in 
18  Nwauzor will be relevant to Plaintiffsโ anticipated summary judgment motion, the Court 
19  will stay consideration of any such motion until Nwauzor is decided.  
20  The Court will not, however, stay discovery related to state law claims.  Defendant 
21  suggests continuing such discovery would be a waste of resources.  Reply at 5โ6.  This 
22  argument ignores, however, that Defendant (1) has had two years to complete only state-
23  law-specific discovery and (2) has repeatedly sought to delay its discovery obligations 
24  despite the advanced age of this case.  See, e.g., ECF No. 224 at 9, 11 (admonishing 
25  Defendant for โdelaying in complying with its discovery obligationsโ and declining to stay 
26  this case with respect to California-focused discovery pending Defendantโs interlocutory 
27  appeal). 
28  / / / 
8 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9994     Page 9
of 11
 
1  Given  the  amount  of  California-focused  discovery  Defendant  has  already 
2  completed2โand  the  extensive  time  the  Parties  have  already  had  to  engage  in  said 
3  discovery3โthe California-focused discovery that remains is unlikely to be sufficiently 
4  burdensome to justify a stay.  And, to the extent Plaintiffs have not yet completed certain 
5  depositions with respect to  state law claims, the risk of loss of evidence due to  the 
6  deteriorating recollections of deponents in this nearly seven-year-old case militates in favor 
7  of allowing said depositions to proceed.  See id. at 9โ10 (denying stay with respect to 
8  California-focused discovery in part because โsome of the relevant information . . . is 
9  known to current and former CoreCivic employees and civil immigration detainees whose 
10  recollections will deteriorateโ).  
11  The Court is concerned, moreover, regarding Defendantโs apparent assumption that 
12  no discovery save ESI production from non-California facilities will occur until February 
13  27, 2025.  See Reply at 5.  It is not clear to the Court why the Parties cannot simultaneously 
14  produce said ESI and complete other outstanding discovery obligations (e.g., the additional 
15  depositions  anticipated  by  Defendant).    To  ensure  that  both  Parties  are  proceeding 
16  diligently with respect to all outstanding fact discovery, the Parties SHALL FILE a 
17  proposed, fact-discovery specific schedule within twenty-one (21) days of the date of this 
18  Order.  This schedule should reflect good faith efforts by both Parties to complete as much 
19  discovery as possible concurrently with Defendantโs ESI production from non-California 
20  facilities.   
21    Finally, the Court will not stay notice to class members until Nwuazor is decided.  
22  As the claims of the National Forced Labor Class are likely to survive regardless of the 
23 
 
24 
2 Defendant represents that it has โproduced over 400,000 pages of documents, including ESI from its 
25  California facilities and Stewart Detention Center.โ  ECF No. 279 at 8 n.9. 
 
26  3 The Court has been generous to Defendant with respect to discovery-related extensions and timelines, 
including by most recently granting Defendant a year to complete document production from its non-
27 
California facilities.  The Courtโs patience for delay, however, is wearing thin.  Going forward, both 
Parties should expect firm, tight deadlines that reflect both the age of this case and the importance of the 
28 
underlying claims. 
9 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9995     Page
10 of 11
 
1  outcome in Nwauzor, notice to said class should go forward.  Moreover, the National 
2  Forced Labor Class by definition overlaps greatly with the California-specific classes.  See 
3  ECF No. 179 at 12 (defining the National Forced Labor Class to include ICE detainees 
4  detained  at  all  CoreCivic  facilities  between  December  23,  2008,  and  the  present).  
5  Declining to proceed with notice to the other two classes alongside notice to the National 
6  Forced Labor Class both risks sacrificing cost savings associated with simultaneous notice 
7  and would likely require adjustments to the already-approved class notice plan, see ECF 
8  No. 206 at 1. 
9  True, courts have stayed notice to class members in cases where the Ninth Circuit 
10  grants (or considers granting) a defendantโs petition to appeal class certification under Rule 
11  23(f).  See, e.g., Brown v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., No. 5:09-CV-03339-EJD, 2012 WL 
12  5818300, at *4โ5 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 15, 2012); Farley v. Lincoln Benefit Life Co., No. 2:20-
13  CV-02485-KJM-DB, 2024 WL 86317, at *4 (E.D. Cal. Jan. 8, 2024).  These courts reason 
14  that if the Ninth Circuit were to reverse or modify the decision certifying the class, a second 
15  curative notice โwould not be sufficient to stem the confusion that would arise.โ  Brown v. 
16  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 2012 WL 5818300, at *4.   
17  This case, however, is distinguishable.  In Nwauzor, the district courtโs decision to 
18  certify a class of civil immigration detainees is not at issue.  See Defendant-Appellantsโ 
19  Opening Brief, supra, at 1โ3.  Nwauzor is therefore not relevant to whether this Court 
20  properly certified the California-specific classes, but instead to the merits of said classesโ 
21  claims.  As this Court is unlikely to alter its certification decision with respect to the 
22  California-specific classes based on the outcome of Nwauzor, the risk of class-member 
23  confusion associated with pre-Nwauzor notice is minimal.4   
24 
25   
26  4 Defendant points out that if the Parties provide notice to all three classes and the state law claims are 
ultimately dismissed, the Parties may then have to bear the cost of a second notice informing class 
27 
members of said dismissal.  Reply at 6.  It is not a given, however, that notice would be required in such 
a circumstance.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(2), (d)(1)(B); cf. Diaz v. Tr. Territory of Pac. Islands, 876 F.2d 
28 
1401, 1406 (9th Cir. 1989) (โRule 23(e) notice is not required where the dismissal is involuntary.โ).  And 
10 
17-CV-1112 JLS (SBC) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-MSB     Document 289     Filed 05/06/24     PageID.9996     Page
11 of 11
 
1  As the Court concludes that class notice should proceed in this case, the Parties 
2  SHALL FILE a proposed class-notice schedule within twenty-one (21) days of the date 
3  of this Order.  If possible, the Court expects class notice to proceed concurrently with, 
4  rather than after, Defendantโs current ESI production. 
5  CONCLUSION 
6    In light of the foregoing, the Court GRANTS IN PART AND DENIES IN PART 
7  Defendantโs Motion to Stay (ECF No. 285).  The Court STAYS this case with respect to 
8  the filing of dispositive motions involving state law claims subject to the constitutional 
9  defenses at issue in Nwauzor.  The Court otherwise DENIES Defendantโs Motion.  The

GOMEZ, on behalf of themselves and all 
12 
others similarly situated,  ORDER STAYING CASE AND 
13  DEFERRING RULING ON MOTION 
Plaintiffs, 
TO DISMISS 
14 
v. 
15  (ECF No. 18) 
CORECIVIC, INC., a Maryland 
16  corporation, 
17  Defendant. 
18 
19  Presently before the Court in the above-captioned action is Defendant CoreCivic, 
20  Inc.โs Motion to Dismiss Complaint, (โMTD,โ ECF No. 18).  Pending before the Court in 
21  the  related  case  Gonzalez v.  CoreCivic,  Inc., 17-cv-2573-JLS  (NLS),  is a  Motion to 
22  Consolidate the present case (Owino) with Gonzalez.  The Motion to Consolidate is set for 
23  hearing on March 22, 2018.  The Court STAYS the present case until the Motion to 
24  Consolidate is resolved and DEFERS RULING ON Defendantโs Motion to Dismiss. 
25  Courts have the power to stay proceedings sua sponte.  Ali v Trump, 241 F. Supp. 3d 
26  1147, 1152 (W.D. Wash. 2017); Fed. Home Loan Mortg. Corp. v. Karma, No. 14-00137 
27  ACK-KSC, 2016 WL 922780, at *8โ9 (D. Haw. Mar. 9, 2016).  The issues involved in the 
28  pending proceedings need not be โcontrolling of the action before the courtโ for the court 
1 
17-CV-1112 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-NLS   Document 33   Filed 02/16/18   PageID.335   Page 2 of 3
1  to issue a stay.  Leyva v. Certified Grocers of Cal., Ltd., 593 F.2d 857, 864 (9th Cir. 1979). 
2  Indeed, for a court to issue a stay, the parties in the two cases need not be the same and the 
3  issues need not be identical.  See Landis v. N. Am. Co., 299 U.S. 248, 254 (1936). 
4  In determining whether to grant a motion to stay, โthe competing interests [that] will 
5  be affected by the granting or refusal to grant a stay must be weighed.โ  Lockyer v. Mirant 
6  Corp., 398 F.3d 1098, 1110 (9th Cir. 2005) (citing CMAX, Inc. v. Hall, 300 F.2d 265, 268 
7  (9th Cir. 1962)).  Those interests include: (1) โthe possible damage which may result from 
8  the granting of a stay,โ (2) โthe hardship or inequity which a party may suffer in being 
9  required to go forward,โ and (3) โthe orderly course of justice measured in terms of the 
10  simplifying or complicating of issues, proof, and questions of law which could be expected 
11  to result from a stay.โ Id.  
12  Here, as to the first factor, the Court finds no damage to Defendant from  the 
13  imposition of a stay in Owino.  The Court anticipates Defendant will file an opposition to 
14  the Motion to Consolidate in Gonzalez, regardless of whether or not the Court were to rule 
15  on the pending Motion to Dismiss in the present case.  The only damage Defendant faces 
16  is a short delay in the resolution of its Motion to Dismiss.  As to the second factor, the 
17  Court finds no hardship to either party in being required to go forward.  The Motion to 
18  Dismiss is briefed by both Parties and a stay will not harm the Parties.  As to the third 
19  factor, the Court finds the stay may lead to the simplification of issues.  If the Court grants 
20  the Motion to Consolidate, it is logical that Defendant will file a Motion to Dismiss in 
21  Gonzalez, and the present Motion to Dismiss will be moot.  If the Court denies the Motion 
22  to Consolidate, the stay in Owino will be lifted and the Court will rule on the Motion to 
23  Dismiss.  The Court finds the imposition of a stay will promote judicial economy.  It is 
24  logical for the Court to determine whether the two cases will be consolidated before the 
25  Court determines whether one of the cases should be dismissed.  The Court exercises its 
26  inherent power to stay the proceeding in order to promote the efficiency of its docket.  See 
27  Landis, 299 U.S. at 254 (holding a court has the inherent power to stay proceedings in order 
28  โto control the disposition of the causes on its docket with economy of time and effort for 
2 
17-CV-1112 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-NLS   Document 33   Filed 02/16/18   PageID.336   Page 3 of 3
1  itself, for counsel, and for litigants.โ); Levya, 593 F.2d at 863โ64 (โA trial court may, with 
2  propriety, find it is efficient for its own docket and the fairest course for the parties to enter 
3  a stay of an action before it, pending resolution of independent proceedings which bear 
4  upon the case.โ). 
5  CONCLUSION 
6  The Court STAYS the present case and DEFERS RULING on the Motion 
7  to Dismiss, (ECF No. 18), until the Motion to Consolidate is resolved. 
8  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
9

1 INTRODUCTION 
2 1.  Plaintiffs  Sylvester  Owino  (โOwinoโ)  and  Jonathan  Gomez  (โGomezโ) 
3 (individually  referred  to  herein  as  a  โPlaintiffโ  and  collectively  as  the  โPlaintiffsโ), 
4 individually and on behalf of all other persons similarly situated, by their undersigned 
5 attorney(s),  for  their  complaint  against  Defendant,  CoreCivic,  Inc.  (โCoreCivicโ  or 
6 โDefendantโ) files this lawsuit to stop CoreCivicโs engagement/implementation of illegal 
7 practices and to obtain damages and restitution from CoreCivic for said practices of 
8 forcing/coercing detainees to clean, maintain, and operate CoreCivicโs detention facilities 
9 in violation of both federal and state human trafficking and labor laws.  Plaintiffs allege 
10 the following based upon personal knowledge as to themselves and their own acts, and 
11 information and belief as to all other matters, and based upon, inter alia, the investigation 
12 conducted by and through their attorneys, which includes, without limitation, a review of 
13 Defendantโs public documents, announcements, and wire and press releases published by 
14 and regarding CoreCivic, and information readily obtainable on the internet. 
15 JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
16 2.  This Court has federal question jurisdiction because this case arises out of 
17 violations of the federal Trafficking in Victims Protection Act under 18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1589, 
18 et seq. (the โTVPAโ).

20 Act, 28 U.S.C. ยง 1332(d) because:  
21 a.  the amount in controversy exceeds $5,000,000, exclusive of interest 
22 and costs;  
23 b.  the proposed Class consists of more than 100 Class Members; and  
24 c.  none of the exceptions under the subsection apply to this action.

1  herein.  The Court DENIES AS MOOT the ex parte Motion to Shorten Time, (ECF No. 
2  33).  On its own motion, the Court VACATES the hearing on the Motion for Limited 
3  Intervention, (ECF No. 32), presently set for March 22, 2018. 
4  BACKGROUND 
5  On May 31, 2017, Sylvester Owino and Jonathon Gomez (the โOwino Plaintiffsโ) 
6  filed suit against Defendant CoreCivic, Inc. in  Owino et al. v. CoreCivic, Inc., No. 17-CV-
7  1112-JLS-NLS.  On August 11, 2017, Defendant CoreCivic filed a motion to dismiss for 
8  failure to state a claim.  Then, on December 27, 2017, Plaintiffs Carlos Gonzalez et al. (the 
9  โGonzalez Plaintiffsโ) filed a complaint against CoreCivic, Inc. in the Gonzalez action, No. 
10  17-CV-2573-JLS-NLS.  On January 22, 2018, the Gonzalez Plaintiffs filed a Motion to 
11  Consolidate Cases and Appoint Interim Lead Class Counsel, (ECF No. 23).  In light of the 
12  Motion to Consolidate and the potential common issues between these two actions, the 
13  Court stayed the Owino et al. v. CoreCivic case and deferred ruling on Defendantโs motion 
14  to dismiss.  The Owino Plaintiffs now seek to intervene in the Gonzalez action for the sole 
15  purpose of opposing the pending Motion to Consolidate. 
16  LEGAL STANDARD 
17  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(a)(2) permits a party to intervene as a matter of 
18  right.    The  Ninth  Circuit  has  adopted  โ[a]  four-part  test  .  .  .  to  determine  whether 
19  applications for intervention as a matter of right pursuant to Rule 24(a)(2) should be 
20  granted.โ  Cnty. of Orange v. Air Cal., 799 F.2d 535, 537 (9th Cir. 1986).  
21  An order granting intervention as of right is appropriate if: (1) 
the applicantโs motion is timely; (2) the applicant has asserted an 
22 
interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject 
23  of  the  action;  (3)  the  applicant  is  so  situated  that  without 
intervention the disposition may, as a practical matter, impair or 
24 
impede its ability to protect that interest; and (4) the applicantโs 
25  interest is not adequately represented by the existing parties. 
26  Id. (quoting United States v. Stringfellow, 783 F.2d 821, 826 (9th Cir. 1986)).  โGenerally, 
27  Rule 24(a)(2) is construed broadly in favor of proposed intervenors and โ[courts] are guided 
28  primarily by practical considerations.โโ  United States ex rel. McGough v. Covington 
2 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 36   Filed 03/06/18   PageID.200   Page 3 of 5
 
1  Techs. Co., 967 F.2d 1391, 1394 (9th Cir. 1992) (quoting Stringfellow, 783 F.2d at 826).  
2  โThe โliberal policy in favor of intervention serves both efficient resolution of issues and 
3  broadened access to the courts.โโ  Peruta v. Cnty. of San Diego, 711 F.3d 570, 577 (9th 
4  Cir. 2014) (Thomas, J., dissenting) (quoting United States v. City of Los Angeles, 288 F.3d 
5  391, 397โ98 (9th Cir. 2002)).  
6    Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(b) provides that an application for permissive 
7  intervention may be granted if the party seeking to intervene โhas a claim or defense that 
8  shares with the main action a common question of law or fact.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(1)(B).  
9  โGenerally, permissive intervention under Rule 24(b) requires โ(1) an independent ground 
10  for jurisdiction; (2) a timely motion; and (3) a common question of law and fact between 
11  the movantโs claim or defense and the main action.โโ  Blum v. Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner 
12  & Smith Inc., 712 F.3d 1349, 1353 (9th Cir. 2013) (quoting Beckman Indus., Inc. v. Intโl 
13  Ins. Co., 966 F.2d 470, 476 (9th Cir. 1992)).  โPermissive intervention is committed to the 
14  broad discretion of the district court.โ  Air Cal., 799 F.2d at 539 (citing United States v. 
15  $129,374  in  U.S.  Currency,  769  F.2d  583,  586  (9th  Cir.  1985)).    โIn  exercising  its 
16  discretion, the court must consider whether the intervention will unduly delay or prejudice 
17  the adjudication or the original partiesโ rights.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(3).  
18    Additionally, โ[t]he district courtโs discretion . . . under Rule 24(b), to grant or deny 
19  an  application  for permissive  intervention  includes  discretion  to  limit  intervention  to 
20  particular issues.โ  Depโt of Fair Empโt & Housing v. Lucent Techs., Inc., 642 F.3d 728, 
21  741 (9th Cir. 2011) (quoting Van Hoomissen v. Xerox Corp., 497 F.2d 180, 181 (9th Cir. 
22  1974)). 
23  ANALYSIS 
24    The Owino Plaintiffs argue that the Court should grant their motion as either an 
25  intervention as a matter of right, under Rule 24(a)(2), or permissive intervention, under 
26  Rule 24(b).  (See ECF No. 32-1, at 3โ11.)  The Court finds that a permissive intervention 
27  under Rule 24(b) is appropriate because the Owino Plaintiffs seek to intervene for the 
28  limited purpose of opposing the Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ Motion to Consolidate.  (See id. at 2.)  
3 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 36   Filed 03/06/18   PageID.201   Page 4 of 5
 
1  In so doing, the Court does not decide the merits of the Owino Plaintiffsโ intervention as a 
2  matter of right.  The Court interprets the Owino Plaintiffsโ motion as limited to opposing 
3  the motion to consolidate, rather than intervening in the case as a party.  This finding, of 
4  course, does not bar the Owino Plaintiffs from moving for such relief in the future.   
5  The Court finds that the Owino Plaintiffsโ Motion for Limited Intervention meets 
6  Rule 24(b)โs requirements.  See Blum, 712 F.3d at 1353.  The Owino Plaintiffs have an 
7  independent ground for jurisdiction as they are properly before the Court in case number 
8  17-CV-1112; their filing is timely because the Motion to Consolidate remains pending; and 
9  the Motion to Consolidate implicates common questions of law and fact because all 
10  Plaintiffs allege violations of law arising out of Defendantโs operation of its Otay Mesa 
11  Detention Facility.  Most importantly, the Owino Plaintiffs represent in their Motion for 
12  Limited Intervention that no party opposes their Motion.  (ECF No. 32, at 2.)  Accordingly, 
13  the Court GRANTS the Owino Plaintiffsโ Motion to Intervene.  However, the Court limits 
14  the  intervention  as  follows:  the  Owino  Plaintiffs  may  oppose,  and  file  briefings  as 
15  necessary to oppose, the Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ Motion to Consolidate, (ECF No. 23). See 
16  Depโt of Fair Empโt & Housing, 642 F.3d at 741.  The Owino Plaintiffs are not, at this 
17  time, parties to the Gonzalez action, No. 17-CV-2573. 
18  CONCLUSION 
19  Good cause appearing, the Court GRANTS the Motion for Limited Intervention, 
20  (ECF No. 32), to the extent detailed above.  The Court DENIES AS MOOT the ex parte 
21  Motion to Shorten Time, (ECF No. 33).  On its own motion, the Court VACATES the 
22  hearing on the Motion for Limited Intervention, presently set for March 22, 2018.  The 
23  Owino Plaintiffs represent that they are prepared to file an Opposition brief to the Motion 
24  to Consolidate on or before March 8, 2018.  (ECF No. 32, at 2.)

20    Presently before the Court is Plaintiffs Carlos Gonzalez, Juan Jose Merino-Rodas, 
21  Maribel  Gutierrez-Canchola,  Gladys  Carrera-Duarte,  and  Jennye  Pagoada-Lopezโs 
22  (โGonzalez  Plaintiffsโ)  Motion  to  Consolidate,  (โMTN,โ  ECF  No.  23).    The  Court 
23  permitted the plaintiffs (โOwino Plaintiffsโ) in a related matter, Owino v. CoreCivic, 17-
24  CV-1112, to intervene for the limited purpose of filing an opposition to this Motion, (ECF 
25  No. 36).  Accordingly, Owino Plaintiffs filed a Response in Opposition, (โOwino Oppโn,โ 
26  ECF No. 37), as did Defendant CoreCivic, Inc., (โDef. Oppโn,โ ECF No. 38), to the 
27  Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ Motion.  The Gonzalez Plaintiffs filed a Reply in Support of, (โReply,โ 
28  ECF No. 41), their Motion.  The Court vacated the hearing and took the matter under 
1 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.367   Page 2 of 10
 
1  submission without oral argument pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7.1(d)(1).  (ECF No. 42.)  
2  Having considered the Partiesโ arguments and the law, the Court rules as follows.   
3  BACKGROUND 
4  This case involves two related class actions.  On May 31, 2017, Owino Plaintiffs 
5  filed a putative class action against Defendant in this Court.  (โOwino Compl.,โ ECF No. 
6  1, Case No. 17-CV-1112.)  The Owino Plaintiffs are former civil immigration detainees 
7  and allege they were paid $1 a day for labor while they were interred at Defendantโs Otay 
8  Mesa Detention Facility.  (Id. ยถ 10.)  They also allege that other detainees were forced to 
9  work for no pay.  (Id. ยถ 13.)  Owino Plaintiffs seek to certify a class of โall civil immigration 
10  detainees  who  performed  Forced  Labor  uncompensated  work  for  CoreCivic  at  any 
11  Detention Facility owned or operated by it between November 2, 2004 to the applicable 
12  opt-out date, inclusive.โ  (Id. ยถ 30.) 
13  On December 27, 2017, Gonzalez Plaintiffs filed a second putative class action 
14  lawsuit against Defendant in the Southern District.  (โGonzalez Compl.,โ ECF No. 1.)  The 
15  case was transferred from Judge Anthony J. Battagliaโs calendar to this Court pursuant to 
16  Civil Local Rule 40.1.  The Gonzalez Plaintiffs, like Owino Plaintiffs, are former civil 
17  immigration detainees housed at Defendantโs Otay Mesa facility.  They allege that they 
18  received $1 or $1.50 a day for their labor at the detention facility.  The Gonzales Plaintiffs 
19  seek to certify classes, including โ[a]ll civil immigration detainees who performed work 
20  for CoreCivic at the Otay Mesa Detention Center in the Work Program within the past ten 
21  years.โ  (Id. ยถ 111.)  Gonzalez Plaintiffs now seek to consolidate the two class actions. 
22  LEGAL STANDARD 
23  Consolidation of actions is appropriate โ[i]f actions before the court involve a 
24  common question of law or fact.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 42(a)(2).  A district court has broad 
25  discretion in determining whether to consolidate actions pending in the same district.  See 
26  Investors Research Co. v. U.S. Dist. Court for Cent. Dist. Of Cal., 877 F.2d 777, 777 (9th 
27  Cir. 1989) (citing 9 Charles A. Wright et al., Federal Practice and Procedure ยง 2383 
28  (1971); and A/S J. Ludwig Mowinckles Rederi v. Tidewater Const. Co., 559 F.2d 928 (4th 
2 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.368   Page 3 of 10
 
1  Cir. 1977)).  โIn determining whether to consolidate cases, a court should also weigh any 
2  time and effort saved by consolidation against any โinconvenience, delay, or expense that 
3  [consolidation] would cause.โโ Fialkov v. Celladon Corp., No. 15CV1458 AJB (DHB), 
4  2015 WL 11658717, at *2 (S.D. Cal. Dec. 9, 2015) (alteration in original) (citing Huene v. 
5  United States, 743 F.2d 703, 704 (9th Cir. 1984)). 
6  ANALYSIS 
7  All parties across both actions agree that the Owino and Gonzalez actions involve 
8  related facts and claims.  The parties diverge, however, on what steps the Court should take 
9  to manage its docket and proceed forward with this case and the Owino case.  Gonzalez 
10  Plaintiffs argue that their action involves common questions of law and fact such that 
11  consolidation of their action with the Owino action would be appropriate.  (See MTN 4.)1  
12  Both Owino Plaintiffs and Defendant argue that the Court should exercise its discretion to 
13  dismiss,  rather  than  consolidate,  the  Gonzalez  action  because  the  Gonzalez  action  is 
14  duplicative of the Owino action.  (Def Oppโn 11; Owino Oppโn 7.)  In response, Gonzalez 
15  Plaintiffs argue that dismissal of their action would be inappropriate because the two 
16  actions are not duplicative.  (Reply 6.)  The Court proceeds as follows.  First, the Court 
17  determines whether the Gonzalez action is duplicative of the Owino action.  Second, the 
18  Court determines which procedural action best serves the interests of judicial economy and 
19  preserves the rights of all parties going forward. 
20  I.  Whether the Gonzalez Action is Duplicative  
21  As a threshold matter, the Court clarifies which rules or standards it applies in the 
22  analysis here.  There are three similar rules the Court could apply to the issue before the 
23  Court.  The Gonzalez Plaintiffs urge the Court apply Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 42, 
24  which permits the Court to consolidate actions involving โcommon question of law or 
25  fact.โ  The Owino Plaintiffs would have the Court adopt a โfirst-to-fileโ rule, which applies 
26  when two similar actions are filed in different federal courts.  Defendant submits the rule 
27 
                                                                 
28 
1 Pin citations refer to the page numbers electronically stamped on the EM/CMF filings. 
3 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.369   Page 4 of 10
 
1  against claim splitting applies, which courts invoke when a plaintiff files two actions 
2  against the same defendant based on the same facts.  District courts in this circuit have 
3  analyzed duplicative class actions under both the first-to-file rule, see Weinstein v. Metlife, 
4  Inc., No. C 06-4444 SI, 2006 WL 3201045, at *4 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 6, 2006), and the claim-
5  splitting rule, see Chowning v. Kohlโs Depโt Stores, Inc., No. CV 15-8673 RGK (SPx), 
6  2016 WL 7655752, at *2 (C.D. Cal. Mar. 2, 2016).  The Court applies the claim-splitting 
7  rule because the first-to-file rule applies to cases between different districts.  See Moore v. 
8  Roadway Express, Inc., No. CV 09-1588, 2009 WL 10670954, at *4 (C.D. Cal. Oct. 7, 
9  2009). 
10  โDistrict courts retain broad discretion to control their dockets and โ[i]n the exercise 
11  of  that  power  they  may  impose  sanctions  including,  where  appropriate,  default  or 
12  dismissal.โโ  Adams v. Cal. Depโt of Health Servs., 487 F.3d 684, 688 (9th Cir. 2007) 
13  (alteration in original) (quoting Thompson v. Hous. Auth. of City of L.A., 782 F.2d 829, 831 
14  (9th Cir. 1986) (per curiam); and citing Link v. Wabash R.R., 370 U.S. 626, 629โ30 (1962)), 
15  abrogated in part by Taylor v. Sturgell, 553 U.S. 880, 904 (2008).  โPlaintiffs generally 
16  have โno right to maintain two separate actions involving the same subject matter at the 
17  same time in the same court and against the same defendant.โโ  Id. (quoting Walton v. Eaton 
18  Corp., 563 F.2d 66, 70 (3d Cir. 1977) (en banc)). 
19  To determine whether a suit is duplicative, courts apply the test for claim preclusion.  
20  See The Haytian Republic, 154 U.S. 118, 124 (1894).  This is a two-part standard.  Thus, a 
21  court must first determine whether the causes of action and relief sought in the two suits 
22  are identical.  Adams, 487 F.3d at 689.  Then a court determines whether the parties, or 
23  their privies, are the same.  Id. 
24  A. Same Causes of Action 
25  To determine whether two causes of action are similar, courts apply a transactional 
26  test.  Id.  โWhether two events are part of the same transaction or series depends on whether 
27  they are related to the same set of facts and whether they could conveniently be tried 
28  together.โ  Id. (quoting W. Sys., Inc. v. Ulloa, 958 F.2d 864, 871 (9th Cir. 1992); and citing 
4 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.370   Page 5 of 10
 
1  Restatement (Second) of Judgments ยง 24(1) (1982)).  Courts examine four criteria: 
2  (1) whether rights or interests established in the prior judgment 
would be destroyed or impaired by prosecution of the second 
3 
action; (2) whether substantially the same evidence is presented 
4  in the two actions; (3) whether the two suits involve infringement 
of the same right; and (4) whether the two suits arise out of the 
5 
same transactional nucleus of facts. 
6   
7  Id. (quoting Costantini v. Trans World Airlines, 681 F.2d 1199, 1201โ02 (9th Cir. 1982)).  
8  โThe last of these criteria is the most important.โ  Constantini, 681 F.2d at 1202. 
9  Gonzalez Plaintiffs argue that while the two actions involve substantially similar 
10  questions of fact and law such that consolidation is appropriate the claims are not identical.  
11  (Reply 7.)  According to Gonzalez Plaintiffs, their Complaint brings five causes of action 
12  compared to the twelve โscattershotโ causes of action brought by Owino Plaintiffs.  (Id.)  
13  Gonzalez Plaintiffs also point to at least two factual differences: they allege that some 
14  members of the putative class were paid more than $1 a day and they allege that Defendant 
15  obtains labor through unlawful means.  (Id.) 
16  Both Owino Plaintiffs and Defendant explain, in detail, the commonality between 
17  the two suits.  For example, both the Gonzalez and Owino Plaintiffs allege that Defendant 
18  pays civil detainees who voluntarily participate in work programs less than the minimum 
19  wage, (Def. Oppโn 7 (comparing Gonzalez Compl. ยถยถ 40โ47, 127, 132 with Owino Compl. 
20  ยถยถ 11, 13โ15, 73, 123)), and that Defendant coerces or forces detainees to work under threat 
21  of solitary confinement or loss of privileges, (id. (comparing Gonzalez Compl. ยถยถ 8, 32, 
22  38โ39, 147โ48, 153โ54 with Owino Compl. ยถยถ 13, 16, 42, 47, 57โ59)).  Both Owino 
23  Plaintiffs and Defendant point to Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ own Motion to Consolidate where 
24  Gonzalez Plaintiffs argue โboth Actions seek to stop the economic exploitation and abuse 
25  of detainees at the Otay Mesa Facility, to recover unpaid wages, and to remedy unjust 
26  enrichment resulting from CoreCivicโs unlawful failure to pay its detainee workforce legal 
27  wages.โ  (Id. (quoting MTN 5); see Owino Oppโn 10โ11.)  Finally, both cases bring causes 
28  of action sounding in violation of the same laws and both cases ask for similar relief.  (Def. 
5 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.371   Page 6 of 10
 
1  Oppโn 9โ10.) 
2  The Court agrees with Owino Plaintiffs and Defendant.  Both cases arise from the 
3  same transactional nucleus of fact.  Both cases argue that Defendant is not following 
4  California minimum wage laws and both cases argue that Defendant coerces its detainees 
5  to participate in a work program at its Otay Mesa detention facility.  Both cases bring 
6  similar causes of action and request similar relief.  Indeed, the entire bases for Gonzalez 
7  Plaintiffsโ Motion of Consolidation are the common questions of law and fact.  The test is 
8  not, as Gonzalez Plaintiffs suggest, whether the two cases are exactly identical.  The test is 
9  transactional.  Here, it is clearly metโthe facts are duplicative. 
10  B. Same Parties 
11  At this point, the Courtโs analysis must diverge from Adams.  The Adams court asked 
12  whether a party in an earlier-filed action could be said to have โvirtually representedโ a 
13  party in a later-filed action.  487 F.3d at 691.  The Supreme Court has since made clear that 
14  โvirtual representationโ is not consonant with the claim preclusion test.  See Taylor, 553 
15  U.S. at 901.  Gonzalez Plaintiffs direct the Court to the Supreme Courtโs decision in Smith 
16  v. Bayer Corp., 564 U.S. 299 (2011), which concerned the preclusive effect of an earlier-
17  filed class action on a later filed class action.  The Supreme Court explained that for claim 
18  preclusion to apply the later filed suit must have presented the same issues as the prior case 
19  and the later filed plaintiff must have been a party to the earlier-filed suit or else fall within 
20  one of a few discrete exceptions to the general rule against binding nonparties.  See id. at 
21  307โ08.  The Supreme Court held that โ[n]either a proposed class action nor a rejected 
22  class action may bind nonparties.โ  Id. at 315. 
23  Here, the Owino Plaintiffs have not been certified as a class under Federal Rule of 
24  Civil Procedure 23.  Instead, Owino is a proposed class action.  The Court agrees with 
25  Gonzalez Plaintiffs that the Owino action cannot bind nonparties, like Gonzalez Plaintiffs.  
26  See Bayer, 553 U.S. at 315.  Because the Owino action does not have preclusive effect 
27  against the Gonzalez Plaintiffs, the claim-splitting rule must also fail.  See Chowning, 2016 
28  WL 7655752, at *3 (applying Bayer to find earlier-filed class action that was rejected in 
6 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.372   Page 7 of 10
 
1  part was not binding on later-filed class action and declining to dismiss later-filed action).  
2  The Court finds that dismissing the Gonzalez action is not appropriate at this time, given 
3  the early stage of the Owino action and that its class has not been certified. 
4  II.  Consolidation vs. Stay 
5    While the claim-splitting rule is not appropriate at this time, such a finding does not 
6  resolve the issue before the Court: how to proceed with two nearly identical putative class 
7  actions.  The district court in Moreno v. Castlerock Farming & Transport, No. CIV-F-12-
8  0556 AWI JLT, 2013 WL 1326496 (E.D. Cal. Mar. 29, 2013), encountered a similar issue.  
9  There, two putative class actions were pending before the same court; neither class action 
10  had been certified.  Id. at *1.  The district court reasoned that the scope of the putative class 
11  in the earlier-filed action would depend greatly on an order granting or denying class 
12  certification.  Id. at *2.  Further, the later-filed class would depend on the scope of the 
13  earlier-filed class.  The court stated:  
14  If the class in [the earlier-filed action] is certified as narrow, then 
the [later-filed] Plaintiffs can move forward to represent all other 
15 
workers  at  [the  defendantโs]  facilities.    Indeed,  all  pre-class 
16  certification discovery received by [earlier-filed plaintiff] could 
be directly given to the [later-filed] Plaintiffs to save time and 
17 
effort in that circumstance.  If the class certified in [the earlier-
18  filed action] is wide, then [the later-filed action] would probably 
be  considered  duplicative  and  subject  to  dismissal.    If  class 
19 
certification is denied for some other reason not having to do 
20  with  [the  earlier-filed  plaintiffโs]  status,  then  [the  later-filed 
action] may or may not be able to proceed depending upon the 
21 
specific circumstance. 
22   
23  Id. (citing Bayer, 564 U.S. at 314). 
24  The Moreno courtโs reasoning and conclusion are persuasive.  Here, the Owino 
25  Plaintiffs  seek  to  certify  sub-classes  potentially  broader  in  scope  than  the  Gonzalez 
26  Plaintiffs.  For example, both lawsuits endeavor to certify a civil detainee sub-class who 
27  performed work for less than Californiaโs minimum wage.   The Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ 
28  putative minimum wage sub-class is limited to all detainees who performed work for 
7 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.373   Page 8 of 10
 
1  Defendant at the Otay Mesa Detention Center within the past ten years.  (Gonzalez Compl. 
2  ยถ 111a.)  The Owino Plaintiffsโ putative minimum wage sub-class covers all detainees at 
3  any facility located in California owned or operated by Defendant between November 2, 
4  2004 and the applicable opt-out date.  (Owino Compl. ยถ 30.)  The remaining sub-classes 
5  follow similar limitations: the Gonzalez Plaintiffs limit the classes to only the Otay Mesa 
6  facility for the past ten years; the Owino Plaintiffs limit the classes to any Defendant-owned 
7  facility in California since 2004.  (Compare Gonzalez Compl. ยถ 111 with Owino Compl. 
8  ยถ 30.) 
9  Thus, the Owino Plaintiffs could potentially certify a broad class that subsumes the 
10  Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ class.  Or, the Owino Plaintiffs could certify a narrower class that does 
11  not include the putative Gonzalez class.  At the pre-certification stage, the Court cannot 
12  determine the size or composition of a class in either case.  Like Moreno, a stay appears to 
13  be the equitable solution.  See also Clardy v. Pinnacle Foods Grp., LLC, No. 16-cv-4385-
14  JST, 2017 WL 57310 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 5, 2017) (staying later-filed class action). 
15  The other course of action is to consolidate the cases.  Certainly, the Gonzalez 
16  Plaintiffs strongly advocate for this outcome.  Yet, both Owino Plaintiffs and Defendant 
17  object to consolidation.  Gonzalez Plaintiffs warns that โit would be an abuse of discretion 
18  to appoint an attorney as class counsel solely because he may have won the race to the 
19  courthouse.โ  (Reply 6 (quoting Northstar Fin. Advisors Inc. v. Schwab Invs., 779 F.3d 
20  1036, 1048 (9th Cir. 2015)).)  Indeed, Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(g) lays out 
21  objective standards to determine appointment of lead class counsel.  Appointment of 
22  interim class counsel, however, is not the issue presently before the Court.  The issue here 
23  is whether to consolidate or whether to stayโnot appointment of interim class counsel.  
24  Courts have the power to stay proceedings sua sponte.  Ali v Trump, 241 F. Supp. 
25  3d 1147, 1152 (W.D. Wash. 2017); Fed. Home Loan Mortg. Corp. v. Karma, No. 14-00137 
26  ACK-KSC, 2016 WL 922780, at *8โ9 (D. Haw. Mar. 9, 2016).  The issues involved in the 
27  pending proceedings need not be โcontrolling of the action before the courtโ for the court 
28  to issue a stay.  Leyva v. Certified Grocers of Cal., Ltd., 593 F.2d 857, 864 (9th Cir. 1979).  
8 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.374   Page 9 of 10
 
1  Indeed, for a court to issue a stay, the parties in the two cases need not be the same and the 
2  issues need not be identical.  See Landis v. N. Am. Co., 299 U.S. 248, 254 (1936). 
3  In determining whether to grant a motion to stay, โthe competing interests [that] will 
4  be affected by the granting or refusal to grant a stay must be weighed.โ  Lockyer v. Mirant 
5  Corp., 398 F.3d 1098, 1110 (9th Cir. 2005) (citing CMAX, Inc. v. Hall, 300 F.2d 265, 268 
6  (9th Cir. 1962)).  Those interests include: (1) โthe possible damage which may result from 
7  the granting of a stay,โ (2) โthe hardship or inequity which a party may suffer in being 
8  required to go forward,โ and (3) โthe orderly course of justice measured in terms of the 
9  simplifying or complicating of issues, proof, and questions of law which could be expected 
10  to result from a stay.โ  Id.  
11  Here, the Court again finds the Moreno courtโs reasoning persuasive as to the first 
12  and second factors.  If the class in Owino is certified as narrow then the Gonzalez Plaintiffs 
13  can move forward to represent all other detainees at Defendantโs facilities.  All pre-class 
14  certification discovery received by Owino Plaintiffs could, in theory, be given to Gonzalez 
15  Plaintiffs to save time and effort.  If the class certified in Owino is wide, then Gonzalez 
16  would probably be considered duplicative and subject to dismissal.  If class certification is 
17  denied for a reason beyond Owino Plaintiffsโ status then Gonzalez Plaintiffs may or may 
18  not be able to proceed.  See Moreno, 2013 WL 1326496, at *2.  The Court recognizes there 
19  is some possibility of damage to the Gonzalez Plaintiffsโif the Owino Plaintiffs certify a 
20  narrow class or their claim is dismissed then the Gonzalez Plaintiffs suffer from the delay 
21  in litigating.  However, the potential damage to the Gonzalez Plaintiffs is mitigated, in part, 
22  because the Court will only stay their proceedings until resolution of the Owino Plaintiffsโ 
23  class certification.2  As to the second factor, the Court finds the hardship on all parties to 
24  be significant if parallel litigation is allowed to proceed on the same issues and the same 
25  Defendant.  On the other hand, the hardship on the Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ is measured in the 
26 
                                                                 
27 
2 This assumes that the Owino Plaintiffs reach the class certification stage. If Defendant prevails on its 
motion to dismiss or some other unforeseen event occurs then the Gonzalez Plaintiffs may request 
28 
appropriate relief from the stay. 
9 
17-CV-2573 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-JLS-NLS   Document 44   Filed 04/04/18   PageID.375   Page 10 of 10
 
1  potential delay in resolving their rights.  As to the third factor, all parties agree that the 
2  Court  should  simplify  the  issues  by  eliminating  the  parallel  proceedings,  either  by 
3  consolidation or by stay or dismissal.  In sum, the Court finds that the Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ 
4  interest is outweighed by the potential claim-splitting concerns as well as judicial economy. 
5  The Court is under no illusion as to the stakes of this Motion.  Gonzalez Plaintiffs 
6  filed a nearly identical cause of action as the Owino Plaintiffs, seek to consolidate the cases, 
7  and wrest control of interim class counsel from the Owino Plaintiffs.  Owino Plaintiffs and 
8  Defendant seek to dismiss the later-filed action as duplicative to send a strong message 
9  against copy-cat filings.  The truth lies somewhere in between.  Thus, the Court exercises 
10  its discretion to chart a course between the two positions.  The Court will stay this case 
11  pending the outcome of Owino Plaintiffsโ future class certification.  At such a time, the 
12  Gonzalez Plaintiffs may request appropriate relief from the stay. 
13  CONCLUSION 
14  For the reasons stated above, the Court DENIES Gonzalez Plaintiffsโ Motion to 
15  Consolidate, (ECF No. 23).  On its own motion, the Court STAYS the present case until it 
16  rules on class certification (or other dispositive motions, such as a motion to dismiss with 
17  prejudice) in Owino. 
18    IT IS SO ORDERED.  
19

1  PLAINTIFFSโ MOTION FOR PARTIAL SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
2  I.  Legal Standard 
3  Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56(a), a party may move for summary 
4  judgment as to a claim or defense or part of a claim or defense.  Summary judgment, or 
5  partial summary judgment, is appropriate where the Court is satisfied that there is โno 
6  genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter 
7  of law.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a); Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 322 (1986).  Material 
8  facts are those that may affect the outcome of the case.  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 
9  477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A genuine dispute of material fact exists only if โthe evidence 
10  is such that a reasonable jury could return a verdict for the nonmoving party.โ  Id.  When 
11  the Court considers the evidence presented by the parties, โ[t]he evidence of the non-
12  movant is to be believed, and all justifiable inferences are to be drawn in his favor.โ  Id. at 
13  255. 
14  The initial burden of establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact falls 
15  on the moving party.  Celotex, 477 U.S. at 323.  The moving party may meet this burden 
16  by identifying the โportions of โthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and 
17  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,โโ that show an absence of dispute 
18  regarding a material fact.  Id.  When a plaintiff seeks summary judgment as to an element 
19  for which it bears the burden of proof, โit must come forward with evidence which would 
20  entitle it to a directed verdict if the evidence went uncontroverted at trial.โ  C.A.R. Transp. 
21  Brokerage Co. v. Darden Rests., Inc., 213 F.3d 474, 480 (9th Cir. 2000) (quoting Houghton 
22  v. South, 965 F.2d 1532, 1536 (9th Cir. 1992)). 
23  Once  the  moving  party  satisfies  this  initial  burden,  the  nonmoving  party  must 
24  identify specific facts showing that there is a genuine dispute for trial.  Celotex, 477 U.S. 
25  at 324.  This requires โmore than simply show[ing] that there is some metaphysical doubt 
26  as to the material facts.โ  Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 
27  586 (1986).  Rather, to survive summary judgment, the nonmoving party must โby her own 
28  affidavits, or by the โdepositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file,โ 
5 
17-CV-1112 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-NLS   Document 179   Filed 04/01/20   PageID.8268   Page 6 of 59
 
1  designate โspecific factsโโ that would allow a reasonable fact finder to return a verdict for 
2  the non-moving party.  Celotex, 477 U.S. at 324; Anderson, 477 U.S. at 248.  The non-
3  moving party cannot oppose a properly supported summary judgment motion by โrest[ing] 
4  on mere allegations or denials of his pleadings.โ Anderson, 477 U.S. at 256. 
5  II.  Analysis 
6  Plaintiffs seek summary adjudication as to (1) their status as โemployeesโ under 
7  California law, and (2) Defendantโs liability to them under California Labor Code sections 
8  226 and 1194 and Industrial Welfare Commission (โIWCโ) Wage Order No. 5-2001.  See 
9  ECF No. 97 at 2.  Defendant contends that Plaintiffsโ motion must be denied because the 
10  โone-way intervention ruleโ precludes Plaintiffs from seeking summary judgment before 
11  class  certification.2    ECF  No.  133  at  3โ4.    Plaintiffs  respond  that  โthe  โone-way 
12  interventionโ rule is a procedural red herring.โ  ECF No. 141 at 9.   
13  The one-way intervention rule is intended โto protect defendants from unfair โone-
14  way intervention,โ where the members of a class not yet certified can wait for the courtโs 
15  ruling on summary judgment and either opt in to a favorable ruling or avoid being bound 
16  by an unfavorable one.โ  Villa v. San Francisco Forty-Niners, Ltd., 104 F. Supp. 3d 1017, 
17  1021 (N.D. Cal. 2015) (citing Am. Pipe & Const. Co. v. Utah, 414 U.S. 538, 547 (1974)).  
18  The one-way intervention rule is supported by โ[t]he purpose of Rule 23(c)(2)[, which] is 
19  to ensure that the plaintiff class receives notice of the action well before the merits of the 
20  case are adjudicated.โ  Schwarzschild v. Tse, 69 F.3d 293, 295 (9th Cir. 1995).  This 
21  purpose is the result of the โ1966 amendments [that] were designed, in part, specifically to 
22  mend this perceived defect in the former Rule and to assure that members of the class 
23  would be identified before trial on the merits and would be bound by all subsequent orders 
24  and judgments.โ  Am. Pipe & Const. Co., 414 U.S. at 547.   
25                                                                   
26  2 Defendant also asks the Court to deny or defer ruling on Plaintiffsโ Motion for Partial Summary 
Judgment until Defendant has had the opportunity to conduct โ[e]ssential [m]erits [d]iscovery.โ  ECF No. 
27 
133 at 6โ10.  Although the Court tends to agree with Plaintiffs that Defendant has not made the requisite 
showing under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56(d), see ECF No. 141 at 2โ8, the Court need not reach 
28 
the issue because the one-way intervention rule is dispositive. 
6 
17-CV-1112 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-NLS   Document 179   Filed 04/01/20   PageID.8269   Page 7 of 59
 
1  While the one-way intervention rule typically precludes a court from ruling on a 
2  merits-based motion before the class is certified and notified, see Schwarzschild, 69 F.3d 
3  at 296, there is an exception โwhen early resolution of a motion for summary judgment 
4  seems likely to protect both the parties and the court from needless and costly further 
5  litigation.โ  Wright v. Schock, 742 F.2d 541, 544 (9th Cir. 1984).  However, โ[d]efendants 
6  must consent to this procedure, as the judgment against the individual plaintiff โwill not be 
7  res judicata as to other individual plaintiffs or other members of any class that may be 
8  certified.โโ  Schwarz v. Meinberg, No. CV1300356BROPLAX, 2016 WL 9115353, at *2 
9  (C.D. Cal. July 15, 2016) (quoting Wright, 742 F.2d at 544); see also Flo & Eddie, Inc. v. 
10  Sirius XM Radio, Inc., No. 13-5693 PSG (RZX), 2015 WL 4476932, at *4 (C.D. Cal. May 
11  27, 2015).  
12  The Court concludes that the one-way intervention rule applies here.  The class was 
13  neither certified nor notified prior to Plaintiffsโ filing of their Motion for Partial Summary 
14  Judgment; consequently, a ruling on the merits is premature because it has the potential to 
15  leave Defendant open to โbeing pecked to deathโ by plaintiffs seeking an alternative 
16  outcome.  See Fireside Bank v. Super. Ct., 40 Cal. 4th 1069, 1078 (2007) (quoting Premier 
17  Elec. Constr. Co. v. Natโl Elec. Contractors Assโn, Inc., 814 F.2d 358, 363 (7th Cir. 1987)).  
18  Further, the exception does not apply here because Defendant did not consent to a pre-
19  certification ruling on Plaintiffsโ Motion for Partial Summary Judgment.  See ECF No. 133 
20  at 4 (โCoreCivic has not consentedโand does not consentโto the adjudication of these 
21  merits issues before a class-certification ruling.โ) (citing Gessele v. Jack in the Box, Inc., 
22  No. 3:10-cv-960-ST, 2012 WL 3686274, at *3 (D. Or. Aug. 24, 2012)). 
23  Because โthere is no reason the briefing on the MPSJ could not have been completed 
24  already as scheduled,โ Plaintiffs suggest that the Court defer ruling on its Motion, without 
25  allowing  Defendant  a  second  opportunity  to  brief  the  merits,  until  after  the  class 
26  certification procedures have been completed.  ECF No. 141 at 9โ10.  But Plaintiffs do not 
27  cite, and the Court has not found, any authority supporting Plaintiffsโ request.  See Gomez 
28  v. Rossi Concrete Inc., No. 08CV1442 BTM CAB, 2011 WL 666888, at *2 (S.D. Cal. Feb. 
7 
17-CV-1112 JLS (NLS) 

Case 3:17-cv-01112-JLS-NLS   Document 179   Filed 04/01/20   PageID.8270   Page 8 of 59
 
1  17, 2011) (denying pre-certification motion for summary judgement without prejudice); 
2  see also Villa, 104 F. Supp. 3d at 1023 (same).  Further, Defendant should not be penalized 
3  for asserting its rights under the one-intervention rule.   
4  Consequently, the Court DENIES WITHOUT PREJUDICE Plaintiffsโ Motion for 
5  Partial Summary Judgment.  Should Plaintiffs elect to renew their Motion for Partial 
6  Summary  Judgment  following  the  Courtโs  resolution  of  their  Motion  for  Class 
7  Certification, Defendant must either respond on the merits or โidentify specific facts to be 
8  obtained in discovery that [a]re essential to oppose summary judgment.โ  See Leonard v. 
9  Baker, 714 F. Appโx 718, 719 (9th Cir. 2018) (citing Family Home & Fin. Ctr., Inc. v. Fed. 
10  Home Loan Mortg. Corp., 525 F.3d 822, 827 (9th Cir. 2008)). 
11  DEFENDANTโS MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
12  I.  Legal Standard 
13  Any party may move for judgment on the pleadings โ[a]fter the pleadings are

15  on the pleadings attacks the legal sufficiency of the claims alleged in the complaint.  See 
16  Patel v. Contemporary Classics of Beverly Hills, 259 F.3d 123, 126 (2d Cir. 2001).  The 
17  Court must construe โall material allegations of the non-moving party as contained in the

19  moving] party.โ  Doyle v. Raleyโs Inc., 158 F.3d 1012, 1014 (9th Cir. 1998).  โJudgment 
20  on the pleadings is proper when the moving party clearly establishes on the face of the 
21  pleadings that no material issue of fact remains to be resolved and that it is entitled to 
22  judgment as a matter of law.โ  Hal Roach Studios, Inc. v. Richard Feiner & Co., Inc., 896 
23  F.2d 1542, 1550 (9th Cir. 1990).  โAnalysis under Rule 12(c) is โsubstantially identicalโ to 
24  analysis under Rule 12(b)(6) because, under both rules, โa court must determine whether 
25  the facts alleged in the complaint, taken as true, entitle the plaintiff to a legal remedy.โโ

26  I.  Legal Standard 
27  Motions for class certification proceed under Rule 23(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil 
28  Procedure. Rule 23(a) provides four prerequisites to a class action:  (1) the class is so

2  questions of law or fact common to the class (โcommonalityโ), (3) the claims or defenses 
3  of the representative parties are typical of the claims or defenses of the class (โtypicalityโ), 
4  and (4) the representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class 
5  (โadequate representationโ).  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
6  A proposed class must also satisfy one of the subdivisions of Rule 23(b).  Here, 
7  Plaintiffs seek to proceed under Rule 23(b)(3), which requires that โthe court find[] that 
8  the  [common  questions]  predominate  over  any  questions  affecting  only  individual 
9  members [โpredominanceโ], and that a class action is superior to other available methods 
10  for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy [โsuperiorityโ].โ  The relevant factors 
11  in this inquiry include the class membersโ interest in individually controlling the litigation, 
12  other litigation already commenced, the desirability (or not) of consolidating the litigation 
13  in this forum, and manageability.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3)(A)โ(D). 
14  โIn determining the propriety of a class action, the question is not whether the 
15  plaintiff or plaintiffs have stated a cause of action or will prevail on the merits, but rather 
16  whether the requirements of Rule 23 are met.โ  Eisen v. Carlisle & Jacquelin, 417 U.S. 
17  156, 178 (1974) (internal quotations omitted).  โRule 23 does not set forth a mere pleading 
18  standard.โ  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 350 (2011).  Rather, โ[a] party 
19  seeking class certification must affirmatively demonstrate his compliance with the Ruleโ
20  that is, he must be prepared to prove that there are in fact sufficiently numerous parties, 
21  common questions of law or fact, etc.โ  Id.  The court is โat liberty to consider evidence 
22  which goes to the requirements of Rule 23 even though the evidence may also relate to the 
23  underlying merits of the case.โ  Hanon v. Dataprods. Corp., 976 F.2d 497, 509 (9th Cir. 
24  1992).  A weighing of competing evidence, however, is inappropriate at this stage of the

4  basis].โ).  As in Tanedo and Novoa, the putative class members share a large number of 
5  common attributes, including that they are immigrants who are or were involuntarily 
6  detained in Defendantโs facilities and subjected to common sanitation and disciplinary 
7  policies.   
8  Third and finally, the Court disagrees with Defendant that the Ninth Circuit does not 
9  permit โclasswide causation evidence,โ such that Novoa and Menocal are inapplicable.  See 
10  ECF No. 164 at 5 n.4 (citing CGC Holding, 773 F.3d 1076; Poulos, 379 F.3d at 668).  The 
11  cases  on  which  Defendant  relies,  CGC  Holding  and  Poulos,  were  both  Racketeer 
12  Influences and Corrupt Organizations cases.  See CGC Holding, 773 F.3d at 1089โ93; 
13  Poulos, 379 F.3d at 664.  To the extent those cases have any bearing in the TVPA context, 
14  see Menocal, 320 F.R.D. at 267 n.5 (acknowledging that CGC Holding did โnot dictate the 
15  outcome in this matterโ), the Ninth Circuitโs โnarrow and case-specificโ decision in Poulos 
16  was based on its determination that โgambling is not a context in which [the court] can 
17  assume that potential class members are always similarly situated.โ  379 F.3d at 665โ66.  
18  In other contexts, such as consumer protection putative class actions, for example, the 
19  Ninth Circuit has recognized that reliance or causation can be inferred on a class-wide basis 
20  where the putative class members are similarly situated; in Walker v. Life Insurance 
21  Company of the Southwest, No. 19-55241, 2020 WL 1329665 (9th Cir. Mar. 23, 2020), for 
22  example, the Ninth Circuit reiterated that in the context of UCL actions โthe operative 
23  question  has  become  whether  the  defendant  so  pervasively  disseminated  material 
24  misrepresentations that all plaintiffs must have been exposed to them.โ  Id. at *5 (citing 
25  Stearns v. Ticketmaster Corp., 655 F.3d 1013, 1020โ21 (9th Cir. 2011), abrogated on other 
26  grounds by Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 569 U.S. 27 (2013)).  The sum total of these 
27  authorities is that an inference of class-wide causation may be permissible where, as here,

4  threats of serious . . . harm to compel Plaintiffs to workโ and โ[c]ommon questions of law

21  detainees is not โsignificant proofโ that โseveral thousandsโ . . . of detainees in California 
22  facilities were subject to their claimed policy.โ  ECF No. 118 at 27.  โFurthermore, 
23  resolving whether each putative class member was in fact a victim of a . . . California TVPA 
24  violation requires the resolution of many individualized inquiries that are particular to each

26    For the same reasons the Court determines that Plaintiffs have established there are 
27  common questions of law and fact that predominate as to the National Forced Labor Class,

1  see supra Section III.C.1.c, the Court also determines that Plaintiffs have met their burden 
2  as to commonality and predominance for the California Forced Labor Class.   
3        e.  Derivative Claims 
4  Plaintiffsโ third cause of action is for violation of the UCL, FAC ยถยถ 63โ70; eleventh 
5  cause of action is for negligence, id. ยถยถ 102โ19; and twelfth cause of action is for unjust 
6  enrichment.  Id. ยถยถ 120โ28.  Plaintiffs acknowledge that each of these causes of action are 
7  derivative of the claims for violations of California labor law, see, e.g., ECF No. 87 at 18, 
8  and California and federal TVPA.  See, e.g., id. at 20.  Consequently, to the extent these 
9  claims are causes of action not barred by the statute of limitations,19 the Court concludes 
10  that common questions predominate to the same  extent discussed above.   See supra 
11  Sections II.C.1.b.iโvii, II.C.1.cโd. 
12    2.  Superiority 
13  The final requirement for class certification is โthat a class action [be] superior to 
14  other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy.โ  Fed R. 
15  Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  โIn determining superiority, courts must consider the four factors of Rule 
16  23(b)(3).โ  Zinser, 253 F.3d at 1190.  The Rule 23(b)(3) factors are: 
17 
(A) [T]he class membersโ interests in individually controlling the 
18  prosecution or defense of separate actions; (B) the extent and 
nature of any litigation concerning the controversy already begun 
19 
by or against class members; (C) the desirability or undesirability 
20  of concentrating the litigation of the claims in the particular 
forum; and (D) the likely difficulties in managing a class action.

restitution.โโ  Astiana v. Hain Celestial Grp., Inc., 783 F.3d 753, 762 (9th Cir. 2015) (quoting Rutherford

Holdings, LLC v. Plaza Del Rey, 223 Cal. App. 4th 221 (2014)) (citing Durell v. Sharp Healthcare, 183
