1  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  The superiority inquiry focuses โon the efficiency and economy 
2  elements of the class action so that cases allowed under [Rule 23(b)(3)] are those that can 
3  be adjudicated most profitably on a representative basis.โ  Zinser, 253 F.3d at 1190 
4  (internal quotation marks omitted).  A district court has โbroad discretionโ in determining 
5  whether class treatment is superior.  Kamm v. Cal. City Dev. Co., 509 F.2d 205, 210 (9th 
6  Cir. 1975). 
7  Plaintiffs contend that a class action is superior here because โmany of the putative 
8  class members have a limited understanding of the law, limited English skills, and limited 
9  resources to devote to pursuing recovery.โ  ECF No. 87 at 25.  โMany former ICE detainees 
10  also  fear  retaliation  given  their  uncertain  immigration  status  or  ongoing  immigration 
11  proceedings.โ  Id. (citing Just Film, Inc. v. Buono, 847 F.3d 1108, 1123 (9th Cir. 2017)).  
12  โFinally, the class members are geographically dispersed given the number of CoreCivic 
13  facilities throughout the United States.โ  Id. (citing In re Monster Worldwide, Inc. Secs. 
14  Litig., 251 F.R.D. 132, 139 (S.D.N.Y. 2008)). 
15  Defendant claims that โPlaintiffs fail to meaningfully address, much less meet their 
16  burden of establishing through evidence, that class treatment is the โsuperiorโ method for 
17  resolving all claims efficiently and economically.โ  ECF No. 118 at 33.  Specifically, 
18  Defendant contends, โ[t]he putative National classes have no meaningful ties to California, 
19  and Plaintiffs provide no reason why this forum is superior.โ  Id. (citing Fed. R. Civ. P. 
20  23(b)(3)(C)).  Defendant claims that this action is not manageable as a class action because 
21  it involves โfive classes, which . . . will include more than 120,000 people who are scattered 
22  across a multitude of countries.โ  Id. at 34.  According to Defendant, individualized 
23  inquiries as to liability and damages also weigh against class certification here.  See id. at 
24  34โ35. 
25  Plaintiffs note that โdamages calculations cannot defeat class certification,โ ECF No. 
26  127 (quoting ECF No. 118 at 35), and note that โCoreCivicโs arguments regarding other 
27  pending  litigation  against  CoreCivicโin  addition  to  demonstrating  the  scope  of 
28  CoreCivicโs enterprise-wide policies and practicesโconfirms that the class members are

1  geographically dispersed.โ  Id. (citing In re Monster Worldwide, Inc. Secs. Litig., 251 
2  F.R.D. at 139).  Further, this is the first-filed of the several class actions to which Defendant 
3  cites โand is the farthest along.โ  Id. 
4  Although Defendant is correct that this action could prove unwieldy, it is also 
5  precisely the sort of action where class-wide litigation is superior to other methods of 
6  litigation.  See Tr. at 28:23โ29:13 (โ[I]f this doesnโt happen on a class basis, it doesnโt 
7  happen. . . .  These detainees are not in a position to take any action. . . .  [A class action] 
8  may be the only way to consider doing this.โ).  Here, โthe โrisks, small recovery, and 
9  relatively high costs of litigationโ make it unlikely that plaintiffs would individually pursue 
10  their claims,โ โconsiderations . . . [that] vividly point[] to the need for class treatment.โ  See 
11  Just Film, Inc., 847 F.3d at 1123; see also Amchem Prods., 521 U.S. at 617 (โThe policy 
12  at the very core of the class action mechanism is to overcome the problem that small 
13  recoveries do not provide the incentive for any individual to bring a solo action prosecuting 
14  his or her rights.โ) (quoting Mace v. Van Ru Credit Corp., 109 F.3d 338, 344 (7th Cir. 
15  1997)).  Further, โlitigation on a classwide basis would promote greater efficiency in 
16  resolving the classesโ claims.โ  Id. at 1123โ24 (citing Valentino v. Carter-Wallace, Inc., 97 
17  F.3d 1227, 1234 (9th Cir. 1996)).  Because no viable alternative method for adjudication 
18  exists, the Court concludes that class-wide litigation is superior.  See, e.g., Leyva v. Medline 
19  Indus. Inc., 716 F.3d 510, 515 (9th Cir. 2013) (concluding that district court erred in 
20  concluding that class action was not superior where โit appears that no[ other means for 
21  putative  class  members  to  adjudicate  their  claims]  exist[s]โ);  see  also  Bennett  v. 
22  GoDaddy.com LLC, No. CV-16-03908-PHX-ROS, 2019 WL 1552911, at *13 (D. Ariz. 
23  Apr. 8, 2019) (โRealistically, the only alternative is for Defendant to avoid effectively all 
24  liability for its actions. . . .  A class action is far superior to the alternative of most of the 
25  allegedly harmed individuals obtaining no relief.โ) (citing Carnegie v. Household Intโl, 
26  Inc., 376 F.3d 656, 661 (7th Cir. 2004)).

PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
13 
1.  This action arises from systematic and unlawful wage theft, unjust enrichment, and 
14 
forced labor at Californiaโs Otay Mesa Detention Center (the โOtay Mesa Facilityโ or the โFacilityโ).  
15 
2.  The Otay Mesa Facility is a civil immigration detention facility owned and operated 
16 
for profit by Defendant CoreCivic, Inc. (โCoreCivicโ).  
17 
18  3.  CoreCivic  is  a  multibillion-dollar  corporation  that  owns  and  operates  detention 
19  facilities across the United States. CoreCivic has made hundreds of millions of dollars in profits from 
20 
its contract to run the Otay Mesa Facility.  
21 
4.  Although it is contractually required to provide for all essential detention services at 
22 
the Facility, CoreCivic uses the free and nearly-free labor of detainees to perform these services to 
23 
maximize profits. 
24

25 
operate the Facility.      
26

1  6.  This labor is not voluntary in any meaningful sense. CoreCivic maintains a corporate 
2 
policy and uniform practice at the Otay Mesa Facility of withholding necessary protection, care, and 
3 
services from its detainees to ensure a ready supply of available labor needed to operate the Facility.  
4 
7.  As a result, detainees are forced to submit to CoreCivicโs unlawful detainee labor 
5 
scheme to buy the basic necessities โ including food, water, warm clothing, medicine, and hygiene 
6 
products โ that CoreCivic unlawfully refuses to provide for them.   
7

8 
9  of threatening detainees who refuse to work with solitary confinement, cutting off communication 
10  and visitation with family, reporting their actions to the United States Immigration and Customs 
11 
Enforcement  (โICEโ),  or  referring  them  for  criminal  prosecution.  Together  with  CoreCivicโs 
12 
systemic under-provision for detainee needs, these abusive practices and threats of abuse ensure that 
13 
detainees will continue working for subminimum wages, or for nothing at all.  
14 
9.  CoreCivicโs  scheme  significantly  reduces  its  labor  costs  and  expenses,  and 
15 
exponentially  increases  its  already  vast  profits,  by  unlawfully  forcing  and  coercing  detainees  to 
16 
perform labor at subminimum wages or for free.  These policies and practices violate California 
17 
18  minimum wage law, the California Unfair Competition Law, and federal and state Trafficking Victims 
19  Protection Acts, which prohibit forced labor.  
20 
10.   Plaintiffs Carlos Gonzalez, Juan Jose Merino-Rodas, Maribel Gutierrez-Canchola, 
21 
Gladys Carrera-Duarte, and Jennye Pagoada-Lopez, individually and on behalf of all others similarly 
22 
situated, brings this class action lawsuit to stop the economic exploitation of detainees at the Otay 
23 
Mesa  Facility,  to  recover  unpaid  wages,  and  to  remedy  the  unjust  enrichment  resulting  from 
24 
CoreCivicโs unlawful failure to pay its detainee workforce legal wages.

JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
26 
27  11.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331 because this 
28  action arises under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act, 18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1589 et seq.

defendant; there are more than 100 class members; the aggregate amount in controversy exceeds

$5,000,000; and minimal diversity exists.

omissions giving rise to the claims occurred in this District.

A.  Plaintiffs

FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
24 
A.  Immigration detention is civilโnot criminal.  
25 
22.  Each  year,  hundreds  of  thousands  of  individuals  are  detained  in  geographically 
26 
27  isolated  immigration  detention  facilities  while  awaiting  immigration  or  citizenship  status 
28 
  5   
 
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02573-AJB-NLS   Document 1   Filed 12/27/17   PageID.6   Page 6 of 25
 
1  determinations.  These  detainees  include  U.S.  citizens,  lawful  permanent  residents  (green  card 
2 
holders) with longstanding family and community ties, survivors of torture, asylum seekers, victims 
3 
of human trafficking, children, and pregnant women.  
4 
23.  Some  detainees  were  brought  to  the  United  States  as  children.  And  thousands 
5 
ultimately have their United States citizenship or legal residency affirmed by an immigration court or 
6 
federal judge. 
7

20 
115.  Typicality: The claims asserted by Plaintiffs are typical of the claims of the Class, in 
21 
that  the  representative  Plaintiffs,  like  all  Class  Members,  were  paid  subminimum  wages  while 
22 
employed by CoreCivic at the Otay Mesa Facility.  Each member of the proposed Class has been 
23 
similarly injured financially by CoreCivicโs misconduct. 
24 
116.  Adequacy: Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the Class. 
25 
Plaintiffs have retained attorneys experienced in class and complex litigation, including wage and 
26 
27  hour class action litigation. Plaintiffs intend to vigorously prosecute this litigation. Neither Plaintiffs 
28  nor their counsel have interests that conflict with the interests of the other class members.  
  18

1  117.  Superiority:  Plaintiffs and Class Members have all suffered and will continue to 
2 
suffer harm and damages as a result of CoreCivicโs wrongful conduct. A class action is superior to 
3 
other available methods for the fair and efficient adjudication of the controversy. Treatment as a class 
4 
action will permit a large number of similarly situated persons to adjudicate their common claims in a 
5 
single forum simultaneously, efficiently, and without the duplication of effort and expense that 
6 
numerous individual actions would engender. Class treatment will also permit the adjudication of 
7 
claims by many members of the proposed class who could not individually afford to litigate a claim 
8 
9  such as is asserted in this complaint. This class action likely presents no difficulties in management 
10  that would preclude maintenance as a class action.  
11 
118.  This action satisfies the requirements of Rule 23(b)(2) because CoreCivic has acted 
12 
and refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the Class, thereby making appropriate final 
13 
injunctive and/or corresponding declaratory relief with respect to each Class Member. 
14

  CALIFORNIA MINIMUM WAGE LAW

19  120.  The California Legislature set the following minimum wages for 2011-2017:10

January 1, 2014  $9.00

26  agreement.

2 
hourly minimum wage.

4 
employees of CoreCivic under California law.

situated, unpaid minimum wages and costs of this suit.

Injured Worker Class, and the Unpaid Cleaner Class.

UNJUST ENRICHMENT 
California Common Law

18  130.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference herein all allegations above. 
19  131.  CoreCivic  materially  and  significantly  reduced  its  labor  costs  and  expenses,  and

increased its profits, because Plaintiffs and Class Members perform undercompensated labor.

22 
performing work for $1 or $1.50 per day, or for nothing at all, for which CoreCivic would otherwise 
23 
have had to pay at least the applicable minimum wage or more, thereby significantly and materially 
24 
increasing CoreCivicโs profits, unjustly enriching CoreCivic at the expense of and detriment to 
25 
Plaintiffs and Class Members. 
26

2 
Class Members have suffered concrete harm and injury, including physical and emotional injury, 
3 
monetary loss, and the unlawful violation of their rights.

135.  Plaintiffs and Class Members are entitled to recover from CoreCivic all amounts that

business acts and practices under the UCL in that CoreCivicโs conduct offends public policy against

forced labor, and seeks to profit by violating Plaintiffsโ rights under state and federal law.

2 
Cal. Civ. Code ยง 52.5 
 
3 
143.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference herein all allegations above. 
4 
144.  Pursuant to the California Trafficking Victims Protection Act, Cal. Civ. Code ยง 52.5, 
5 
โa victim of human trafficking, as defined in Section 236.1 of the Penal Code, may bring a civil action 
6 
for actual damages, compensatory damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, any combination of 
7 
those, or any other appropriate relief.โ  
8 
9  145.  Human trafficking is defined as the deprivation or violation of the personal liberty of 
10  another โwith the intent to obtain forced labor or services.โ Cal. Penal Code ยง 236.1. 
11 
146.  Forced  labor  or  services  is  defined  as  โlabor  or  services  that  are  performed  or 
12 
provided by a person and are obtained or maintained through force, fraud, duress, or coercion, or 
13 
equivalent  conduct  that  would  reasonably  overbear  the  will  of  the  person.โ Cal.  Penal  Code 
14 
ยง 236.1(h)(5). 
15 
147.  CoreCivic  materially  and  significantly  reduced  its  labor  costs  and  expenses,  and 
16 
increased its profits, by unlawfully forcing and coercing Plaintiffs and Class Members to perform 
17 
18  uncompensated labor. In order to drive profits, CoreCivic acted with the intent to obtain forced 
19  labor or services from its detainees.  
20 
148.  As alleged herein, CoreCivic did not and does not provide detainees at the Otay Mesa 
21 
Facility with sufficient provisions and necessities for daily life. In order to purchase these necessary 
22 
items, including food, medicine, hygiene products, and clothing, Plaintiffs and Class Members were 
23 
and are forced or coerced to perform labor and services for CoreCivic for $1 or $1.50 per day.  
24 
149.  Plaintiffs and Class Members are entitled to recover from CoreCivic all amounts that 
25 
CoreCivic has wrongfully and improperly obtained, and CoreCivic should be required to disgorge to 
26 
27  Plaintiffs and Class Members the benefits it has unjustly obtained. Plaintiffs and Class Members are 
28  also entitled to recover exemplary damages. C.R.S. ยง 13- 21-102.

 ATTEMPTED FORCED LABOR

18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1589(a) & 1594(a)

6 
18 U.S.C. ยง 1589(a).

8 
9  and uniform practice at the Otay Mesa Facility aimed at obtaining nearly free detainee labor and

them to work for subminimum wages in order to buy those daily necessities for 
12 
themselves and avoid serious harm, including, but not limited to, malnutrition,

confinement; and

b.  Threatening Plaintiffs and Class Members with physical restraint, serious harm, 
15  and abuse of law or legal process if they refuse to provide their labor, organize a 
work stoppage, or participate in a work stoppage. 
16 
 
154.  CoreCivic further violated 18 U.S.C. ยง 1589 by maintaining a corporate policy and 
17 
18  uniform practice at the Otay Mesa Facility of threatening Plaintiffs and Class Members with serious 
19  harm, including solitary confinement, referral to an ICE officer, or criminal prosecution if they 
20 
refused to work. 
21 
155.  CoreCivic attempted to perpetrate the offense of forced labor against Plaintiffs and 
22 
Class Members.  
23 
156.  CoreCivic knowingly benefitted financially from participation in a venture CoreCivic 
24 
knew or should have known engaged in unlawful coercion of labor in violation of 18 U.S.C. ยง 1589. 
25 
157.  Plaintiffs and Class Members have suffered damages in an amount to be determined 
26 
27  at trial.  
28 
  23
